We denote the average attention weight over H heads as am‚Å¢j=1H‚Å¢‚àëh=1Ham‚Å¢j(h)subscriptùëéùëöùëó1ùêªsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé1ùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëöùëó‚Ñéa_{mj}=\tfrac{1}{H}\sum_{h=1}^{H}a_{mj}^{(h)}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and correspondingly ùêöm‚âú[am‚Å¢j]j=1Jm‚âúsubscriptùêöùëösuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëéùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see the FLM at the bottom of Fig. 2).

In FLMs, these last-layer CLS embeddings are used as document-level representations for downstream tasks (e.g., document classification). Furthermore, our VALC assumes KùêæKitalic_K concepts (topics) for the corpus. For document mùëömitalic_m, our VALC interpreter tries to infer a concept distribution vector ùúΩm‚àà‚ÑùKsubscriptùúΩùëösuperscript‚Ñùùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (also known as the topic proportion in topic models) for the whole document and a concept distribution vector œïm‚Å¢j=[œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k]k=1K‚àà‚ÑùKsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëósuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòùëò1ùêæsuperscript‚Ñùùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}=[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for word jùëójitalic_j in document mùëömitalic_m. In our continuous embedding space, the kùëòkitalic_k‚Äôth concept is represented by a Gaussian distribution, ùí©‚Å¢(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)ùí©subscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), of contextual word embeddings; we use shorthand ùõÄk=(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)subscriptùõÄùëòsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for brevity. The goal is to interpret FLMs‚Äô predictions at the concept level using the inferred document-level concept vector ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, word-level concept vector œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the learned embedding distributions {ùí©‚Å¢(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptùí©subscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K}{ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for each concept (see Sec. 5.4 for detailed descriptions and visualizations).

3.2 Formal Definition of Language Concepts

Below we formally define ‚Äòconceptual interpretation‚Äô for FLM predictions (see notations in Sec. 3.1):

Definition 3.1 (Conceptual Interpretation).

Assume KùêæKitalic_K concepts and a dataset ùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D containing MùëÄMitalic_M documents, each with JmsubscriptùêΩùëöJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT words (1‚â§m‚â§M1ùëöùëÄ1\leq m\leq M1 ‚â§ italic_m ‚â§ italic_M). Conceptual interpretation for a document mùëömitalic_m consists of KùêæKitalic_K dataset-level variables {ùõÄk}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõÄùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a document-level variable ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and JmsubscriptùêΩùëöJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT word-level variables {œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the following properties:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Conceptual interpretation has a three-level structure:

    1. (a)

      Each dataset-level variable ùõÄk=(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)subscriptùõÄùëòsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})bold_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) describes the kùëòkitalic_k‚Äôth concept; ùùÅk‚àà‚ÑùdsubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùö∫k‚àà‚Ñùd√ódsubscriptùö∫ùëòsuperscript‚Ñùùëëùëë\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d\times d}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d √ó italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the mean and covariance of the kùëòkitalic_k‚Äôth concept in the embedding space (i.e., ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àà‚Ñùdsubscriptùêûùëöùëósuperscript‚Ñùùëë{\bf e}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), respectively.

    2. (b)

      Each document-level variable ùúΩm‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0KsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptsuperscript‚Ñùùêæabsent0\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes document mùëömitalic_m‚Äôs relation to the KùêæKitalic_K concepts.

    3. (c)

      Each word-level variable œïm‚Å¢j‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0Ksubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëósubscriptsuperscript‚Ñùùêæabsent0\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}_{\geq 0}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT describes word jùëójitalic_j‚Äôs relation to the KùêæKitalic_K concepts.

  2. (2)

    Normalization. The document- and word-level interpretations, ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are normalized:

    1. (a)

      ‚àëk=1KŒ∏m‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùúÉùëöùëò1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for document mùëömitalic_m.

    2. (b)

      ‚àëk=1Kœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for word jùëójitalic_j in document mùëömitalic_m.

  3. (3)

    Additivity. We can add/subtract the kùëòkitalic_k‚Äôs concept from the contextual embeddings ùêûm‚Å¢jsubscriptùêûùëöùëó{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of word jùëójitalic_j in document mùëömitalic_m, i.e., ùêûm‚Å¢j‚Üêùêûm‚Å¢j¬±xk‚Å¢ùùÅk‚Üêsubscriptùêûùëöùëóplus-or-minussubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùùÅùëò{\bf e}_{mj}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{mj}\pm x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬± italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (xksubscriptùë•ùëòx_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the editing weight of concept kùëòkitalic_k).

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. The conceptual interpretation achieves maximum mutual information between the observed embeddings ùêûmsubscriptùêûùëö{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in FLMs and the document-level/word-level interpretation, ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In Definition 3.1, Property (1) provides comprehensive three-level conceptual interpretation for FLM predictions, Property (2) ensures proper normalization in concept assignment at the document and word levels, Property (3) enables better concept editing (more details in Sec. 5.3) to modify FLM predictions, and Property (4) ensures minimal information loss when interpreting FLM predictions.

3.3 VAriational Language Concepts (VALC)

Method Overview. Drawing inspiration from hierarchical Bayesian deep learning Wang and Yeung (2016, 2020); Wang et al. (2016); Mao et al. (2022); Yan and Wang (2023); Xu et al. (2023); Wang et al. (2024), we propose our model, VAriational Language Concepts (VALC), to infer the optimal conceptual interpretation described in Definition 3.1. Different from static word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013) and topic models, FLMs produce contextual word embeddings with continuous-value entries [ùêûm‚Å¢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùêûùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and more importantly, associate each word embedding with a continuous-value attention weight [am‚Å¢j]j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëéùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}[ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; therefore this brings unique challenges.

To effectively discover latent concept structures learned by FLMs at the dataset level and interpret FLM predictions at the data-instance level, our VALC treats both the contextual word embeddings and their associated attention weights as observations to learn a probabilistic generative model of these observations, as shown in Fig. 2. The key idea is to use the attention weights from FLMs to compute a virtual continuous count for each word, and model the contextual word embedding distributions with Gaussian mixtures. The generative process of VALC is as follows (we mark key connection to FLMs in blue and show the corresponding graphical model in Fig. 3):

For each document m,1‚â§m‚â§Mùëö1ùëöùëÄm,1\leq m\leq Mitalic_m , 1 ‚â§ italic_m ‚â§ italic_M,

  1. 1.

    Draw the document-level concept distribution vector ùúΩm‚àºDirichlet‚Å¢(ùú∂)similar-tosubscriptùúΩùëöDirichletùú∂\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}\sim\text{Dirichlet}(\mbox{\boldmath$% \alpha$\unboldmath})bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº Dirichlet ( bold_italic_Œ± ).

  2. 2.

    For each word jùëójitalic_j (1‚â§j‚â§Jm)1ùëósubscriptùêΩùëö(1\leq j\leq J_{m})( 1 ‚â§ italic_j ‚â§ italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

    1. (a)

      Draw the word-level concept index zm‚Å¢j‚àºCategorical‚Å¢(ùúΩm)similar-tosubscriptùëßùëöùëóCategoricalsubscriptùúΩùëöz_{mj}\sim\text{Categorical}(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº Categorical ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

    2. (b)

      With a continuous word count wm‚Å¢j‚àà‚Ñùsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó‚Ñùw_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R from the FLM‚Äôs attention weights, draw the contextual word embedding of the FLM from the corresponding Gaussian component ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àºùí©‚Å¢(ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)similar-tosubscriptùêûùëöùëóùí©subscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó{\bf e}_{mj}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Given the generative process above, discovery of latent concept structures in FLMs at the dataset level boils down to learning the parameters {ùùÅk,ùö∫k}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the KùêæKitalic_K concepts. Intuitively the global parameters {ùùÅk,ùö∫k}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% \}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are shared across different documents, and they define a mixture of KùêæKitalic_K Gaussian distributions. Each Gaussian distribution describes a ‚Äòcluster‚Äô of words and their contextual word embeddings.

Similarly, interpretations of FLM predictions at the data-instance level is equivalent to inferring the latent variables, i.e., document-level concept distribution vectors ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level concept indices zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Below we highlight several important aspects of our VALC designs.

Attention Weights as Continuous Word Counts. Different from typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) and word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013) that can only handle discrete word counts, our VALC can handle continuous (virtual) word counts; this better aligns with continuous attention weights in FLMs. Specifically, we denote as wm‚Å¢j‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0subscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscript‚Ñùabsent0w_{mj}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\geq 0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â• 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the (non-negative real-valued) continuous word count for the jùëójitalic_j‚Äôth word in document mùëömitalic_m. We explore three schemes of computing wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëów_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Identical Weights: Use identical weights for different words, i.e., wm‚Å¢j=1,‚àÄm,jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó1for-allùëöùëów_{mj}=1,\forall m,jitalic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , ‚àÄ italic_m , italic_j. This is equivalent to typical discrete word counts.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Attention-Based Weights with Fixed Length: Use wm‚Å¢j=J‚Ä≤‚Å¢am‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósuperscriptùêΩ‚Ä≤subscriptùëéùëöùëów_{mj}=J^{\prime}a_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where J‚Ä≤superscriptùêΩ‚Ä≤J^{\prime}italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a fixed sequence length shared across all documents.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Attention-Based Weights with Variable Length: Use wm‚Å¢j=Jm‚Å¢am‚Å¢j/‚àëi=1Jmam‚Å¢isubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùëéùëöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùëéùëöùëñw_{mj}=\nicefrac{{J_{m}a_{mj}}}{{\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = / start_ARG italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, where JmsubscriptùêΩùëöJ_{m}italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is true sequence length without padding. Note that in practice, ‚àëi=1Jmam‚Å¢i‚â†1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùëéùëöùëñ1\sum_{i=1}^{J_{m}}a_{mi}\neq 1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† 1 due to padding tokens in FLMs.

Contextual Continuous Word Representations. Note that different from topic models (Blei et al., 2003) and typical word embeddings (Mikolov et al., 2013; Dieng et al., 2020) where word representations are static, word representations in FLMs are contextual; specifically, the same word can have different embeddings in different documents (contexts). For example, the word ‚Äòsoft‚Äô can appear as the j1subscriptùëó1j_{1}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôth word in document m1subscriptùëö1m_{1}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and as the j2subscriptùëó2j_{2}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôth word in document m2subscriptùëö2m_{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and therefore have two different embeddings (i.e., ùêûm1‚Å¢j1‚â†ùêûm2‚Å¢j2subscriptùêûsubscriptùëö1subscriptùëó1subscriptùêûsubscriptùëö2subscriptùëó2{\bf e}_{m_{1}j_{1}}\neq{\bf e}_{m_{2}j_{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚â† bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Correspondingly, in our VALC, we do not constrain the same word to have a static embedding; instead we assume that a word embedding is drawn from a Gaussian distribution corresponding to its latent topic. Note that word representations in our VALC is continuous, which is different from typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003) based on (discrete) bag-of-words representations.

3.4 Objective Function

Below we discuss the inference and learning procedure for VALC. We start by introducing the inference of document-level and word-level concepts (i.e., zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) given the global concept parameters (i.e., {(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and then introduce the learning of these global concept parameters.

3.4.1 Inference

Inferring Document-Level and Word-Level Concepts. We formulate the problem of interpreting FLM predictions at the concept level as inferring document-level and word-level concepts. Specifically, given global concept parameters {(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the contextual word embeddings ùêûm‚âú[ùêûm‚Å¢j]j=1Jm‚âúsubscriptùêûùëösuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùêûùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö{\bf e}_{m}\triangleq[{\bf e}_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the associated attention weights ùêöm‚âú[am‚Å¢j]j=1Jm‚âúsubscriptùêöùëösuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùëéùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö{\bf a}_{m}\triangleq[a_{mj}]_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a FLM produces for each document mùëömitalic_m, our VALC infers the posterior distribution of the document-level concept vector ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùêûm,ùêöm,{(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1K)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùêûùëösubscriptùêöùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæp(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf a}_{m},\{(\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1% }^{K})italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and the posterior distribution of the word-level concept index zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., p‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|ùêûm,ùêöm,{(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1K)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëösubscriptùêöùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæp(z_{mj}|{\bf e}_{m},{\bf a}_{m},\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox% {\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Variational Distributions. These posterior distributions are intractable; we therefore resort to variational inference (Jordan et al., 1998; Blei et al., 2003) and use variational distributions q‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∏m)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùú∏ùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|œïm‚Å¢j)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóq(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to approximate them. Here ùú∏m‚àà‚ÑùKsubscriptùú∏ùëösuperscript‚Ñùùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and œïm‚Å¢j‚âú[œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k]k=1K‚àà‚ÑùK‚âúsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëósuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòùëò1ùêæsuperscript‚Ñùùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\triangleq[\phi_{mjk}]_{k=1}^{K}\in{% \mathbb{R}}^{K}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚âú [ italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are variational parameters to be estimated during inference. This leads to the following joint variational distribution:

q‚Å¢(ùúΩm,{ùê≥m‚Å¢j}j=1Jm|ùú∏m,{œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jm)ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëöconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê≥ùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùú∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö\displaystyle q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{{\bf z}_{mj}\}_{j=1}% ^{J_{m}}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= q‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∏m)‚ãÖ‚àèj=1Jmq‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|œïm‚Å¢j).‚ãÖùëûconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùú∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptproductùëó1subscriptùêΩùëöùëûconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\displaystyle q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma% $\unboldmath}_{m})\cdot\prod\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}q(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$% \phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}).italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚ãÖ ‚àè start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (1)

Evidence Lower Bound. For each document mùëömitalic_m, finding the optimal variational distributions is then equivalent to maximizing the following evidence lower bound (ELBO):

‚Ñí‚Å¢(ùú∏m,{œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jm;ùú∂,{(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1K)‚Ñísubscriptùú∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëöùú∂superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{% \boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$% \unboldmath},\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œ± , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∂)]+‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm)]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëöùú∂superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùúΩùëö\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|% \mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})]+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_% {q}[\log p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ± ) ] + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
+‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)]superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó\displaystyle+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|% z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]+ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
‚àíùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùúΩm)]‚àí‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j)],subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùëßùëöùëó\displaystyle-{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})% ]-\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log q(z_{mj})],- blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (2)

where the expectation is taken over the joint variational distribution in Eq. 1.

Likelihood with Continuous Word Counts. One key difference between VALC and typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) is the virtual continuous (real-valued) word counts (discussed in Sec. 3.3). Specifically, we define the likelihood in the third term of Eq. 2 as:

p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)=[ùí©‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j;ùùÅm‚Å¢j,ùö∫m‚Å¢j)]wm‚Å¢j.ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëósuperscriptdelimited-[]ùí©subscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëöùëósubscriptùö∫ùëöùëósubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})=[{\mathcal{N}}({\bf e}_{mj};% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj}% )]^{w_{mj}}.italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Note that Eq. 3 is the likelihood of wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëów_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (virtual) words, where wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëów_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a real value derived from the FLM‚Äôs attention weights (details in Sec. 3.3). Therefore, in the third item of Eq. 2, we have:

ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
=\displaystyle=~{}= ‚àëkœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢log‚Å°ùí©‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùùÅk,ùö∫k)subscriptùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëóùí©conditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{{k}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\log{\mathcal{N}}({\bf e}_{mj}% |\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=\displaystyle=~{}= ‚àëkœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢kwm‚Å¢j{‚àí12(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)Tùö∫k‚àí1(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{{k}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{% k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚àílog[(2œÄ)d/2|ùö∫k|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_œÄ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (4)

Update Rules. Taking the derivative of the ELBO in Eq. 2 w.r.t. œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ksubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò\phi_{mjk}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Appendix A for details) and setting it to 00 yields the update rule for œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ksubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò\phi_{mjk}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚àùproportional-tosubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòabsent\displaystyle\phi_{mjk}\propto~{}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àù wm‚Å¢j|ùö∫k|1/2exp[Œ®(Œ≥m‚Å¢k)‚àíŒ®(‚àëk‚Ä≤Œ≥m‚Å¢k‚Ä≤)\displaystyle\tfrac{w_{mj}}{|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}}% \exp[\Psi(\gamma_{mk})-\Psi(\sum\nolimits_{k^{\prime}}\gamma_{mk^{\prime}})divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_exp [ roman_Œ® ( italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Œ® ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚àí12(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)Tùö∫k‚àí1(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)],\displaystyle-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^% {T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})],- divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] , (5)

with the normalization constraint ‚àëk=1Kœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.

Œ≥m‚Å¢k=Œ±k+‚àëj=1Jmœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j,subscriptùõæùëöùëòsubscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle\gamma_{mk}=\alpha_{k}+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj},italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (6)

where ùú∂‚âú[Œ±k]k=1K‚âúùú∂superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùõºùëòùëò1ùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}\triangleq[\alpha_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_italic_Œ± ‚âú [ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hyperparameter for the Dirichlet prior distribution of ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In summary, the inference algorithm will alternate between updating œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ksubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò\phi_{mjk}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,j,k)ùëöùëóùëò(m,j,k)( italic_m , italic_j , italic_k ) tuples and updating ùú∏m‚Å¢ksubscriptùú∏ùëöùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{mk}bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all (m,k)ùëöùëò(m,k)( italic_m , italic_k ) tuples.

3.4.2 Learning

Learning Dataset-Level Concept Parameters. The inference algorithm in Sec. 3.4.1 assumes availability of the dataset-level (global) concept parameters {(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To learn these parameters, one needs to iterate between (1) inferring document-level variational parameters ùú∏msubscriptùú∏ùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as word-level variational parameters œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Sec. 3.4.1 and (2) learning dataset-level concept parameters {(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Update Rules. Similar to Sec. 3.4.1, we expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 (see Appendix A for details) and set its derivative w.r.t. ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ùüé0{\bf 0}bold_0, yielding the update rule for learning ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ùùÅk=subscriptùùÅùëòabsent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j,subscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}{\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}{\bf e}_{mj}}}{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{% mjk}w_{mj}},divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,
ùö∫k=subscriptùö∫ùëòabsent\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}=~{}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)T‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j.subscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòùëásubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (7)

Effect of Attention Weights. From Eq. 7, we can observe that the attention weight of the jùëójitalic_j‚Äôth word in document mùëömitalic_m, i.e., am‚Å¢jsubscriptùëéùëöùëóa_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, affects the virtual continuous word count wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëów_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Sec. 3.3), thereby affecting the update of the dataset-level concept center ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and covariance ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, if we use attention-based weights with fixed length or variable length in Sec. 3.3, the continuous word count wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùë§ùëöùëów_{mj}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be proportional to the attention weight am‚Å¢jsubscriptùëéùëöùëóa_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, when updating the concept center ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a weighted average of different word embeddings ùêûm‚Å¢jsubscriptùêûùëöùëó{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, VALC naturally places more focus on words with higher attention weights am‚Å¢jsubscriptùëéùëöùëóa_{mj}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs, thereby making the interpretations sharper (see Sec. 5.4 for detailed results and Appendix I for theoretical analysis).

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide theoretical guarantees of VALC on the four properties in Definition 3.1.

Multi-Level Structure. As shown in Alg. 1, VALC (1) learns the dataset-level interpretation {ùõÄk}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõÄùëòùëò1ùêæ\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Omega$\unboldmath}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}{ bold_Œ© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describing the KùêæKitalic_K concepts, (2) infers the distribution of document-level interpretation ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document mùëömitalic_m, i.e., q‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∏m)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùú∏ùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (parameterized by ùú∏msubscriptùú∏ùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and (3) infers the posterior distribution of word-level concept index, i.e., q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|œïm‚Å¢j)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóq(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), parameterized by œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Such three-level interpretations correspond to Property (1) in Definition 3.1.

Normalization. The learned variational distribution q‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∏m)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùú∏ùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (described in Eq. 1) is a Dirichlet distribution; therefore we have ‚àëk=1KŒ∏m‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùúÉùëöùëò1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. The update of œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Eq. 3.4.1) is naturally constrained by ‚àëk=1Kœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mjk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 since œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameterizes a Categorical distribution (over zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Additivity. VALC is able to perform Concept Editing, i.e, add/subtract the learned concept activation Œºksubscriptùúáùëò\mu_{k}italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from FLMs via the following Quadratic Programming (QP) problem (ùê±=[xk]k=1Kùê±superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùë•ùëòùëò1ùêæ{\bf x}=[x_{k}]_{k=1}^{K}bold_x = [ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT):

minùê±‚àà‚ÑùKsubscriptùê±superscript‚Ñùùêæ\displaystyle\min\nolimits_{{\bf x}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}}\quadroman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Äñ‚àëk=1Kxk‚Å¢ùùÅk‚àíùêûm‚Äñ2,superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùêûùëö2\displaystyle\|\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k% }-{\bf e}_{m}\|^{2},‚à• ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
subject to ùê±‚â•ùüé‚Å¢ and ‚Å¢‚àëk=1Kxk=1.ùê±0 and superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùë•ùëò1\displaystyle{\bf x}\geq{\bf 0}\mbox{~{}~{}and~{}~{}}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}x_% {k}=1.bold_x ‚â• bold_0 and ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 . (8)

Given learned concepts {(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1KsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, VALC obtains this QP‚Äôs optimal solution ùê±‚àó‚àà‚ÑùKsuperscriptùê±superscript‚Ñùùêæ{\bf x}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and add/subtract any concept kùëòkitalic_k from arbitrary FLM embedding ùêûmsubscriptùêûùëö{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by: ùêûm‚Üêùêûm¬±xk‚àó‚Å¢ùùÅk.‚Üêsubscriptùêûùëöplus-or-minussubscriptùêûùëösubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùùÅùëò{\bf e}_{m}\leftarrow{\bf e}_{m}\pm x^{*}_{k}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_% {k}.bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ¬± italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Alg. 2 summarizes this concept editing process; one can also replace ùêûm‚Å¢jsubscriptùêûùëöùëó{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the CLS embedding ùêúmsubscriptùêúùëö{\bf c}_{m}bold_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document-level editing (details in Appendix 3).

Mutual Information Maximization. Theorem 4.1 below shows that our inferred document-level and word-level interpretation, ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jmsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{ bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfy Property (4), Mutual Information Maximization, in Definition 3.1.

Theorem 4.1 (Mutual Information Maximization).

In Eq. 2, the ELBO ‚Ñí‚Å¢(ùõÑm,{œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jm;ùõÇ,{(ùõçk,ùö∫k)}k=1K)‚ÑísubscriptùõÑùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëöùõÇsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõçùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œ± , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is upper bounded by the mutual information between contextual embeddings ùêûmsubscriptùêûùëö{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and multi-level interpretation ùõâm,{œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jmsubscriptùõâùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{% mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Definition 3.1. Formally, with approximate posteriors q‚Å¢(ùõâm|ùõÑm)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùõâùëösubscriptùõÑùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|œïm‚Å¢j)ùëûconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptbold-œïùëöùëóq(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we have

‚Ñí‚Ñí\displaystyle\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L (ùú∏m,{œïm‚Å¢j}j=1Jm;ùú∂,{(ùùÅk,ùö∫k)}k=1K)subscriptùú∏ùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëöùú∂superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\displaystyle(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$% \unboldmath}_{mj}\}_{j=1}^{J_{m}};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{(\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})\}_{k=% 1}^{K})( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œ± , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
‚â§\displaystyle\leq~{}‚â§ I‚Å¢(ùêûm;ùúΩm,{zm‚Å¢j}j=1Jm)‚àíH‚Å¢(ùêûm),ùêºsubscriptùêûùëösubscriptùúΩùëösuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëßùëöùëóùëó1subscriptùêΩùëöùêªsubscriptùêûùëö\displaystyle{I}({\bf e}_{m};\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},\{z_{mj}% \}_{j=1}^{J_{m}})-H({\bf e}_{m}),italic_I ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (9)

where the entropy term H‚Å¢(ùêûm)ùêªsubscriptùêûùëöH({\bf e}_{m})italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a constant.

From Theorem 4.1 we can see that maximizing the ELBO in Eq. 2 is equivalent to maximizing the mutual information between our document-level/word-level concepts and the observed contextual embeddings in FLMs (proof in Appendix H).

In summary, VALC enjoys all four properties in Definition 3.1 and therefore generates the optimal conceptual interpretation for FLMs. In contrast, state-of-the-art methods only satisfy a small part of them (Table 1 and Sec. 5.2). In Appendix I, we provide theoretical guarantees that (1) under mild assumptions our VALC can learn better conceptual interpretations for FLMs for in noisy data and (2) attention-based schemes is superior to the identical scheme (described in Sec. 3.3).

5 Experiments

5.1 Experiment Setup

Datasets. We use three datasets in our experiments, namely 20 Newsgroups, M10 (Lim and Buntine, 2015), and BBC News (Greene and Cunningham, 2006). For preprocessing details, see Appendix C.

Baselines. We compare our method with the following state-of-the-art baselines:

  • ‚Ä¢

    SHAP and LIME (Lundberg and Lee, 2017; Ribeiro et al., 2016) are interpretation methods that attribute importance scores to input features. In this paper, we use embeddings of ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô token as input to SHAP/LIME.

  • ‚Ä¢

    BERTopic (Grootendorst, 2020) is a clustering-based model that uses HDBSCAN (McInnes and Healy, 2017) to cluster sentence embeddings from BERT, performs Uniform Manifold Approximation Projection (UMAP) (McInnes et al., 2018), and then uses class-based TF-IDF (c-TF-IDF) to obtain words for each cluster.

  • ‚Ä¢

    CETopic (Zhang et al., 2022) is a clustering-based model that first uses UMAP to perform dimensionality reduction on BERT sentence embeddings, performs K-Means clustering (Lloyd, 1982), and then uses weighted word selection for each cluster.

Evaluation Metric. Inspired by Koh et al. (2020), we perform concept editing experiments to evaluate conceptual interpretation for FLMs; higher accuracy gain after editing indicates better interpretation performance. We leverage BERT-base-uncased (Devlin et al., 2018) as the contextual embedding model, and use accuracy on the test set as our metric. For a fair comparison, we adhered to the baseline methodologies (e.g., BERTopic and CETopic) by setting the number of concepts (topics) KùêæKitalic_K to 100 across all datasets. This number was chosen as it strikes an effective balance between capturing adequate detail and avoiding model overfitting. See Appendix D for more details.

We can perform concept editing on either input tokens or contextual embeddings of FLMs. Specifically, we can perform hard concept editing for concept kùëòkitalic_k by directly removing tokens that belong concept kùëòkitalic_k (applicable for hard clustering methods such as our baselines); we could also perform soft concept editing for concept kùëòkitalic_k by removing concept subspace vectors from contextual embeddings ùêûmsubscriptùêûùëö{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (applicable for VALC using Alg. 2).

Following Lyu et al. (2024), we conducted additional experiments to evaluate the faithfulness metric. The faithfulness metric is implemented as the accuracy score of predictions using logistic regression, with the inferred conceptual explanations as inputs.

5.2 Comparison on Four Properties in Definition 3.1

In Sec. 4 we show that VALC satisfies the four properties of conceptual interpretation in Definition 3.1. In contrast, baseline models do not necessarily learn concepts that meet these requirements. Table 1 summarizes the comparison between VALC and the baselines. We can see that VALC is superior to baselines in terms of the following four aspects:

  1. (1)

    Multi-Level Structure. Baselines either apply clustering algorithms directly on the document-level embeddings from FLMs or assign importance scores to input features, and thus can only provide single-level interpretation, necessitating complex post-processing to generate dataset-level concepts. In contrast, VALC adopts an integrated approach, learning concepts at the dataset, document, and word level in a joint, end-to-end manner.

  2. (2)

    Normalization. BERTopic and CETopic assign each word to exactly one concept and therefore satisfies hard-normalization. SHAP/LIME produce importance scores that are not normalized. In contrast, VALC learns fractional concept interpretations ùú∏msubscriptùú∏ùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore satisfies soft-normalization, which is more flexible and intuitive.

  3. (3)

    Additivity. Baselines perform addition or subtraction of concepts only at a single level (word/document), while our additivity and concept editing (Alg. 2) work for both levels.

  4. (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization. Baselines either use a multi-step pipeline or produce importance scores; they are therefore prone to lose information between FLM embeddings and final clustering/scoring results. In contrast, VALC is theoretically guaranteed to maximally preserve information (Theorem 4.1).

5.3 Results

Accuracy Gain. We perform greedy concept editing (Koh et al., 2020) for BERTopic, CETopic, and our VALC to evaluate the quality of their learned concepts. Higher accuracy gain after pruning indicates better performance.

Table 2 show the results for different methods in three real-world datasets, where ‚ÄòFinetune (Oracle)‚Äô refers to finetuning both the backbone and the classifier of BERT. VALC‚Äôs concept editing can improve the accuracy upon the unedited model by more than 11%percent1111\%11 % in 20 Newsgroups and M10, almost on par with ‚ÄòFinetune (Oracle)‚Äô. Compared with the baselines, VALC achieves the most accuracy gain in 20 Newsgroups and M10 and the second most accuracy gain in BBC News, demonstrating the effectiveness of VALC‚Äôs four properties in Definition 3.1. Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS token‚Äôs embedding and therefore has identical accuracy gain (details in Appendix D).

Ablation Study. Thanks to its full additivity (Definition 3.1), VALC is capable of different concept editing schemes, including ‚ÄòRandom‚Äô, ‚ÄòUnweighted‚Äô, and ‚ÄòWeighted‚Äô. Specifically, weighted pruning uses the concept editing algorithm in Alg. 2 with the optimal hyperparameter œâùúî\omegaitalic_œâ; unweighted pruning runs Alg. 2 with œâ=1ùúî1\omega=1italic_œâ = 1; random pruning first randomly picks a concept kùëòkitalic_k (k‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,K}ùëò1‚Ä¶ùêæk\in\{1,...,K\}italic_k ‚àà { 1 , ‚Ä¶ , italic_K }), sets œâ‚ãÖxk=1/K‚ãÖùúîsubscriptùë•ùëò1ùêæ\omega\cdot x_{k}=1/Kitalic_œâ ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 / italic_K, and then runs Alg. 2.

Table 3 shows accuracy for VALC‚Äôs different schemes. As expected, random pruning barely improves upon the unedited model. Unweighted pruning improves upon the unedited model by 1.5‚àº3.5%similar-to1.5percent3.51.5\sim 3.5\%1.5 ‚àº 3.5 %. Weighted pruning improves the accuracy by around 11%percent1111\%11 % upon the unedited model on 20 Newsgroups and M10.

Faithfulness. Table 4 shows the faithfulness of VALC and baselines on the 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News datasets. These results show that our VALC significantly outperforms the baseline models, achieving the highest faithfulness accuracy scores in the 20 Newsgroups (89.8%percent89.889.8\%89.8 %), M10 (99.5%percent99.599.5\%99.5 %), and BBC News (100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %) datasets.

Note that the dataset size of 20 Newsgroups, M10, and BBC News is 16,3091630916{,}30916 , 309, 8,35583558{,}3558 , 355, and 2,22522252{,}2252 , 225, respectively. BBC News contains significantly less data, making it easier to achieve a high faithfulness score. This explains why both CETopic and our VALC obtain a faithfulness score of 100.0%percent100.0100.0\%100.0 %.

Baseline methods such as BERTopic and CETopic represent language concepts as discrete bags of words, which lack flexibility and accuracy. In contrast, VALC infers continuous concepts for datasets, documents, and words with theoretical guarantees. Consequently, it provides optimal and faithful conceptual explanations of high quality.

See Appendix G for more quantitative results.

5.4 Conceptual Interpretation (More for Different Tasks in Appendix F)

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As a case study, we train VALC on M10, sample 6666 concepts (topics) from the dataset, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA in Fig. 4(left and middle). We can observe Concept 5 is mostly about data analysis, including words such as ‚Äòsampling‚Äô and ‚Äòsimilarity‚Äô. Concept 84 is mostly about reasoning, with words ‚Äòexplore‚Äô, ‚Äôaccept‚Äô, ‚Äòexplain‚Äô, etc. Concept 62 is mostly about nature, with words ‚Äòenvironment‚Äô, ‚Äòformation‚Äô, ‚Äògrowth‚Äô, etc. Concept 98 is mostly about farming, with words ‚Äòterm‚Äô, ‚Äòsummer‚Äô, ‚Äòheating‚Äô, etc. Concept 24 is mostly about economics, with words ‚Äòforthcoming‚Äô, ‚Äòprospect‚Äô, ‚Äògrow‚Äô, etc. Concept 74 is mostly about social contact, containing words such as ‚Äòpeer‚Äô, ‚Äòconnect‚Äô, and ‚Äòcollaborative‚Äô. Interestingly, Concept 24 (economics) and Concept 74 (social contact) are both related to social science and are therefore closer to each other in Fig. 4(middle), while Concept 98 (farming) is farther away, showing VALC‚Äôs cability of capturing concept similarity.

Document-Level Interpretations. Fig. 4(right) shows that VALC can provide conceptual interpretations on why correct or incorrect FLM predictions happen for specific documents. For example, document (e) belongs to class 2 (biology), but BERT misclassifies it as class 9 (social science); our VALC interprets that this is because document (e) involves Concept 24 (economics), which is related to social science. On the other hand, document (b) is related to machine learning and BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science); VALC interprets that this is because document (b) involves Concept 5 (data analysis).

Word-Level Interpretations. Fig. 4(right) also shows that VALC can interpret which words and what concepts of these words lead to specific FLM predictions. For example, document (f) belongs to class 7 (petroleum chemistry), but BERT misclassifies it as class 0 (agriculture); VALC attributes this to the word ‚Äòair‚Äô, which belongs to Concept 98 (farming). For document (b), VALC interprets that BERT correctly classifies it as class 3 (computer science) because the document contains the word ‚Äòkernel‚Äô that belongs to Concept 5 (data analysis).

6 Conclusion

We address the challenge of multi-level interpretations for FLM predictions by defining conceptual interpretation and introducing VALC, the first method to infer such interpretations effectively. Empirical results are promising, and theoretical analysis confirms that VALC reliably produces optimal conceptual interpretations by our definition.

7 Limitations

Our proposed method assumes access to the hidden layers of Transformer-based models, and therefore can be naturally extended to Transformer-based models including RoBERTa Liu et al. (2019), DeBERTa He et al. (2021), ALBERT Lan et al. (2019), Electra Clark et al. (2020), and decoder-only models, such as GPTs Radford et al. (2019); Brown (2020). Although our VALC is initially designed for Transformer-based models, it is also generalizable to other architectures, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) LeCun et al. (2015) and Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTMs) Hochreiter and Schmidhuber (1997), by simply setting identical attention weights. Future work may include extending VALC beyond Transformer variants and natural language applications. However, many other foundation language models provided by proprietary sources may not expose their internal states, limiting the applicability of our method in such cases.

8 Ethical Considerations

VALC, as the first to comprehensively interpret FLMs at the concept level, holds significant promise for advancing societal and technological progress. By elucidating the inner workings of these complex FLMs, we enable greater transparency and trust in AI systems, which is crucial for their widespread adoption. This transparency ensures that AI-driven decisions in critical areas such as healthcare, law, and finance are more explainable and accountable, thus safeguarding against biases and errors. Additionally, our VALC fosters enhanced collaboration between AI and human experts, as interpretable models can provide insights that are more easily understood and acted upon by domain specialists. This symbiotic relationship has the potential to accelerate innovation, improve decision-making processes, and ultimately lead to more ethical and equitable AI applications, thereby benefiting society at large.

9 Acknowledgements

We also express our deep appreciation to Microsoft Research AI & Society Fellowship, NSF Grant IIS-2127918, NSF CAREER Award IIS-2340125, NIH Grant 1R01CA297832, and the Amazon Faculty Research Award for their generous support. This research is also supported by NSF National Artificial Intelligence Research Resource (NAIRR) Pilot and the Frontera supercomputer supported by the National Science Foundation (award NSF-OAC 1818253) at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at The University of Texas at Austin. Additionally, we thank the anonymous reviewers and the area chair/senior area chair for their thoughtful feedback and for recognizing the significance and contributions of our research. Finally, we would like to thank the Center for AI Safety (CAIS) for providing the essential computing resources that enabled this work.
