Appendix A Details on Learning VALC

Update Rules. Similar to Sec. 3.4.1 of the main paper, we expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 of the main paper, take its derivative w.r.t. ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and set it to ùüé0{\bf 0}bold_0:

‚àÇL‚àÇùùÅk=‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ùö∫k‚àí1‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)=0,ùêøsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1subscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëò0\displaystyle\tfrac{\partial L}{\partial\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}}=% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}% _{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})=0,divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 , (10)

yielding the update rule for learning ùùÅisubscriptùùÅùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j,absentsubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle=\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}{\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}{\bf e}_{mj}}}{\sum_{m,j}\phi_% {mjk}w_{mj}},= divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (11)

where ùö∫k‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is canceled out. Similarly, setting the derivatives w.r.t. ùö∫ùö∫\Sigmabold_Œ£ to ùüé0{\bf 0}bold_0, i.e.,

‚àÇL‚àÇùö∫k=12‚Å¢‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢(‚àíùö∫k‚àí1+ùö∫k‚àí1‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)T‚Å¢ùö∫k‚àí1),ùêøsubscriptùö∫ùëò12subscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1subscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòùëásuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1\displaystyle\tfrac{\partial L}{\partial\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% }}=\tfrac{1}{2}\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}(-\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{k}^{-1}+\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_% {k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1}),divide start_ARG ‚àÇ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG ‚àÇ bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (12)

we have

ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)T‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j.absentsubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòùëásubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\displaystyle=\tfrac{\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$% \mu$\unboldmath}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}}{% \sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}}.= divide start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (13)

Smoothing with Prior Distributions on {(Œºk,ùö∫k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùúáùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëò1ùêæ\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k% })\}_{k=1}^{K}{ ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To alleviate overfitting and prevent singularity in numerical computation, we impose priors distributions on ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to smooth the learning process (Fig. 5). Specifically, we use a Normal-Inverse-Wishart prior on ùùÅisubscriptùùÅùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫isubscriptùö∫ùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àº‚Ñê‚Å¢ùí≤‚Å¢(ùö≤0,ŒΩ0),similar-toabsent‚Ñêùí≤subscriptùö≤0subscriptùúà0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{IW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0},\nu_{0}),‚àº caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ŒΩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,
ùùÅk|ùö∫kconditionalsubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àºùí©‚Å¢(ùùÅ0,ùö∫k/Œ∫0),similar-toabsentùí©subscriptùùÅ0subscriptùö∫ùëòsubscriptùúÖ0\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0},\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}/\kappa_{0}),‚àº caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where ùö≤0subscriptùö≤0\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ŒΩ0subscriptùúà0\nu_{0}italic_ŒΩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ùùÅ0subscriptùùÅ0\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Œ∫0subscriptùúÖ0\kappa_{0}italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are hyperparameters for the prior distributions. Taking the expectations of ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the posterior distibution ùí©‚Å¢‚Ñê‚Å¢ùí≤‚Å¢(ùùÅk,ùö∫k|ùùÅk(n),ùö≤k(n),Œ∫k(n),ŒΩk(n))ùí©‚Ñêùí≤subscriptùùÅùëòconditionalsubscriptùö∫ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùùÅùëòùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùö≤ùëòùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúÖùëòùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúàùëòùëõ\mathcal{NIW}(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}|\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\mbox{\boldmath$% \Lambda$\unboldmath}_{k}^{(n)},\kappa_{k}^{(n)},\nu_{k}^{(n)})caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ŒΩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we have the update rules as:

ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üêùîºùí©‚Å¢‚Ñê‚Å¢ùí≤‚Å¢[ùùÅk]=Œ∫0‚Å¢ùùÅ0+nk‚Å¢ùùÅ~kŒ∫0+nk,‚Üêabsentsubscriptùîºùí©‚Ñêùí≤delimited-[]subscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùúÖ0subscriptùùÅ0subscriptùëõùëòsubscript~ùùÅùëòsubscriptùúÖ0subscriptùëõùëò\displaystyle\leftarrow{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{NIW}}[\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{k}]=\tfrac{\kappa_{0}\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0}+n_{k}% \widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}}{\kappa_{0}+n_{k}},‚Üê blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (14)
ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üêùîºùí©‚Å¢‚Ñê‚Å¢ùí≤‚Å¢[ùö∫k]=ùö≤0+ùêík+Œ∫0‚Å¢nkŒ∫0+nk‚Å¢(ùùÅ~k‚àíùùÅ0)‚Å¢(ùùÅ~k‚àíùùÅ0)TŒΩ0+nk‚àíK‚àí1,‚Üêabsentsubscriptùîºùí©‚Ñêùí≤delimited-[]subscriptùö∫ùëòsubscriptùö≤0subscriptùêíùëòsubscriptùúÖ0subscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùúÖ0subscriptùëõùëòsubscript~ùùÅùëòsubscriptùùÅ0superscriptsubscript~ùùÅùëòsubscriptùùÅ0ùëásubscriptùúà0subscriptùëõùëòùêæ1\displaystyle\leftarrow{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{NIW}}[\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{k}]=\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\Lambda$\unboldmath}_{0}+{\bf S}_{k}+% \tfrac{\kappa_{0}n_{k}}{\kappa_{0}+n_{k}}(\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}}_{k}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0})(\widetilde{\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{0})^{T}}{\nu% _{0}+n_{k}-K-1},‚Üê blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N caligraphic_I caligraphic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG bold_Œõ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Œ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ŒΩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K - 1 end_ARG , (15)
ùêíksubscriptùêíùëò\displaystyle{\bf S}_{k}bold_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅ~k)‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅ~k)T.absentsubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëósubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscript~ùùÅùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscript~ùùÅùëòùëá\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}({\bf e}_{mj}-\widetilde{% \mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k})({\bf e}_{mj}-\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath% $\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k})^{T}.= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (16)

where nk=‚àëm,jœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëöùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëón_{k}=\sum_{m,j}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the total virtual word counts used to estimate ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 are the smoothed version of Eq. 7 of the main paper. From the Bayesian perfective, they correspond to the expectations of ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôs and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôs posterior distributions. Alg. 1 of the main paper summarizes the learning of VALC.

Online Learning of Œºksubscriptùúáùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that FLMs are deep neural networks trained using minibatches of data, while Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 need to go through the whole dataset before each update. Inspired by Hoffman et al. (2010); Oord et al. (2017), we using exponential moving average (EMA) to work with minibatchs. Specifically, we update them as:

ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ÜêœÅ‚ãÖN‚ãÖùùÅk+(1‚àíœÅ)‚ãÖB‚ãÖùùÅ~k,‚Üêabsent‚ãÖùúåùëÅsubscriptùùÅùëò‚ãÖ1ùúåùêµsubscript~ùùÅùëò\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}+(1% -\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k},‚Üê italic_œÅ ‚ãÖ italic_N ‚ãÖ bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_œÅ ) ‚ãÖ italic_B ‚ãÖ over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ÜêœÅ‚ãÖN‚ãÖùö∫k+(1‚àíœÅ)‚ãÖB‚ãÖùö∫~k,‚Üêabsent‚ãÖùúåùëÅsubscriptùö∫ùëò‚ãÖ1ùúåùêµsubscript~ùö∫ùëò\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N\cdot\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}% +(1-\rho)\cdot B\cdot\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k},‚Üê italic_œÅ ‚ãÖ italic_N ‚ãÖ bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_œÅ ) ‚ãÖ italic_B ‚ãÖ over~ start_ARG bold_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,
NùëÅ\displaystyle Nitalic_N ‚ÜêœÅ‚ãÖN+(1‚àíœÅ)‚ãÖB,‚Üêabsent‚ãÖùúåùëÅ‚ãÖ1ùúåùêµ\displaystyle\leftarrow\rho\cdot N+(1-\rho)\cdot B,‚Üê italic_œÅ ‚ãÖ italic_N + ( 1 - italic_œÅ ) ‚ãÖ italic_B ,
ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\displaystyle\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚ÜêùùÅkN,ùö∫k‚Üêùö∫kN,formulae-sequence‚ÜêabsentsubscriptùùÅùëòùëÅ‚Üêsubscriptùö∫ùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëòùëÅ\displaystyle\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},\quad% \mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}\leftarrow\tfrac{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma% $\unboldmath}_{k}}{N},‚Üê divide start_ARG bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üê divide start_ARG bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ,

where BùêµBitalic_B is the minibatch size, NùëÅNitalic_N is a running count, and œÅ‚àà(0,1)ùúå01\rho\in(0,1)italic_œÅ ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) is the momentum hyperparameter. ùùÅ~ksubscript~ùùÅùëò\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Œº end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫~ksubscript~ùö∫ùëò\widetilde{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}}_{k}over~ start_ARG bold_Œ£ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the updated ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùö∫ksubscriptùö∫ùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT after applying Eq. 14 and Eq. 15 only on the current minibatch.

Effect of Attention Weights. Interestingly, we also observe that FLMs‚Äô attention weights on stop words such as ‚Äòthe‚Äô and ‚Äòa‚Äô tend to be much lower; therefore VALC can naturally ignore these concept-irrelevant stop words when learning and inferring concepts (as discussed in Sec. 3.4.2). This is in contrast to typical topic models (Blei et al., 2003; Blei, 2012) that require preprocessing to remove stop words.

Phrase-Level Interpretations. We can easily infer phrase-level concepts from word-level concepts by treating phrases as sub-documents and adapting Eq. 6 (which provides document-level concepts) in the paper. Specifically, suppose for a given phrase spanning from the rùëüritalic_r-th word to the sùë†sitalic_s-th word in document mùëömitalic_m, we can adapt Eq. 6 to provide phrase-level conceptual explanations as Œ≥m‚Å¢k(r,s)=Œ±k+‚àëj=rsœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢jsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëöùëòùëüùë†subscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëóùëüùë†subscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}=\alpha_{k}+\sum_{j=r}^{s}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here Œ≥m‚Å¢k(r,s)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëöùëòùëüùë†\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the strength of concept kùëòkitalic_k for the given phrase in document mùëömitalic_m. In this way, Œ≥m‚Å¢k(r,s)superscriptsubscriptùõæùëöùëòùëüùë†\gamma_{mk}^{(r,s)}italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_r , italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can serve as the phrase-level concept explanation of the phrase spanning from rùëüritalic_r-th word to the sùë†sitalic_s-th word; this is another interesting complementary sub-document-level concept explanation between the word level and the document level.

Appendix B Interpretation of the ELBO

VALC‚Äôs evidence lower bound (ELBO), i.e., Eq. 2 in the paper, is

‚Ñí‚Å¢(ùú∏m,{œïm‚Å£[1:Jm]};Œ±,{(ùùÅ[1:K],ùö∫[1:K])})‚Ñísubscriptùú∏ùëösubscriptbold-italic-œïùëödelimited-[]:1subscriptùêΩùëöùõºsubscriptùùÅdelimited-[]:1ùêæsubscriptùö∫delimited-[]:1ùêæ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{m},\{\mbox{% \boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{m[1:J_{m}]}\};\alpha,\{(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}_{[1:K]},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{[1:K]})\})caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m [ 1 : italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ; italic_Œ± , { ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 : italic_K ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } ) =ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|Œ±)]+‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùê≥m‚Å¢j|ùúΩm)]absentsubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëöùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùúΩùëö\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|% \alpha)]+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf z}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ± ) ] + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
+‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œºùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œ£ùê≥m‚Å¢j)]superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùúásubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptŒ£subscriptùê≥ùëöùëó\displaystyle+\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{% \bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]+ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
‚àíùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùúΩm)]‚àí‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùê≥m‚Å¢j)].subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùê≥ùëöùëó\displaystyle-\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]-% \sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log q({\bf z}_{mj})].- blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] . (17)

Derivation of the Evidence Lower Bound. We derive the evidence lower bound by computing the log likelihood of each term. For example, by definition, p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œºùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œ£ùê≥m‚Å¢j)=[ùí©‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j;ùùÅm‚Å¢j,ùö∫m‚Å¢j)]wm‚Å¢jùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùúásubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptŒ£subscriptùê≥ùëöùëósuperscriptdelimited-[]ùí©subscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëöùëósubscriptùö∫ùëöùëósubscriptùë§ùëöùëóp({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})=[% \mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj};\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath% $\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{mj})]^{w_{mj}}italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ùí©‚Å¢(‚ãÖ)ùí©‚ãÖ\mathcal{N}(\cdot)caligraphic_N ( ‚ãÖ ) is the Gaussian distribution. Then we derive the third term ‚àëj=1Jmùîºùï¢‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œºùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œ£ùê≥m‚Å¢j)]superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùï¢delimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùúásubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptŒ£subscriptùê≥ùëöùëó\sum_{j=1}^{J_{m}}\mathbb{E_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}% _{mj}},\Sigma_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] in Eq. B as follows:

ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùê≥m‚Å¢j,Œºùê≥m‚Å¢j,ùö∫ùê≥m‚Å¢j)]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùúásubscriptùê≥ùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùê≥ùëöùëó\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|{\bf z}_{mj},\mu_{{\bf z}_{mj}% },\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{{\bf z}_{mj}})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] =‚àëkœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢log‚Å°ùí©‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|ùùÅk,ùö∫k)absentsubscriptùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëóùí©conditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsubscriptùö∫ùëò\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\log\mathcal{N}({\bf e}_{mj}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k})= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log caligraphic_N ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=‚àëkœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢kwm‚Å¢j{‚àí12(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)Tùö∫k‚àí1(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
‚àílog[(2œÄ)d/2|ùö∫k|1/2]}.\displaystyle-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}% ]\}.- roman_log [ ( 2 italic_œÄ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (18)

Expanding the ELBO to the Loss Function. We can expand the ELBO in Eq. 2 of the main paper as:

‚Ñí‚Å¢(ùú∏,œï;ùú∂,{ùùÅ}k=1K,{ùö∫}k=1K)=‚Ñíùú∏bold-italic-œïùú∂superscriptsubscriptùùÅùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1ùêæabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath},\mbox{\boldmath$% \phi$\unboldmath};\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$% \unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K},\{\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}\}_{k=1}^{K})=caligraphic_L ( bold_italic_Œ≥ , bold_italic_œï ; bold_italic_Œ± , { bold_italic_Œº } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , { bold_Œ£ } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = log‚Å°ùö™‚Å¢(‚àëk=1KŒ±k)‚àí‚àëk=1Klog‚Å°ùö™‚Å¢(Œ±k)+‚àëk=1K(Œ±k‚àí1)‚Å¢(Œ®‚Å¢(ùú∏k)‚àíŒ®‚Å¢(‚àëk‚Ä≤=1Kùú∏k‚Ä≤))ùö™superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæùö™subscriptùõºùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùõºùëò1Œ®subscriptùú∏ùëòŒ®superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤1ùêæsubscriptùú∏superscriptùëò‚Ä≤\displaystyle\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\alpha_{k})% -\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\alpha_{k})+\sum_{k=1}^% {K}(\alpha_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{% \prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))roman_log bold_Œì ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Œì ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Œ® ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Œ® ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+‚àëj=1J‚àëk=1Kœïj‚Å¢k‚Å¢(Œ®‚Å¢(ùú∏k)‚àíŒ®‚Å¢(‚àëk‚Ä≤=1Kùú∏k‚Ä≤))superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëóùëòŒ®subscriptùú∏ùëòŒ®superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤1ùêæsubscriptùú∏superscriptùëò‚Ä≤\displaystyle+\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$% \gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$% \unboldmath}_{k^{\prime}}))+ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Œ® ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Œ® ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
+‚àëj,kœïj‚Å¢k‚Å¢wj‚Å¢{‚àí12‚Å¢(ùêûj‚àíùùÅk)T‚Å¢ùö∫k‚àí1‚Å¢(ùêûj‚àíùùÅk)‚àílog‚Å°[(2‚Å¢œÄ)d/2‚Å¢|ùö∫k|1/2]}subscriptùëóùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëó12superscriptsubscriptùêûùëósubscriptùùÅùëòùëásuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1subscriptùêûùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscript2ùúãùëë2superscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò12\displaystyle+\sum_{j,k}\phi_{jk}w_{j}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{j}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}+ ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_œÄ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] }
‚àílog‚Å°ùö™‚Å¢(‚àëk=1Kùú∏j)+‚àëk=1Klog‚Å°ùö™‚Å¢(ùú∏k)‚àí‚àëk=1K(ùú∏k‚àí1)‚Å¢(Œ®‚Å¢(ùú∏k)‚àíŒ®‚Å¢(‚àëk‚Ä≤=1Kùú∏k‚Ä≤))ùö™superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùú∏ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæùö™subscriptùú∏ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùú∏ùëò1Œ®subscriptùú∏ùëòŒ®superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤1ùêæsubscriptùú∏superscriptùëò‚Ä≤\displaystyle-\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$\unboldmath}(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{j})+\sum_{k=1}^{K}\log\mbox{\boldmath$\Gamma$% \unboldmath}(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k})-\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\mbox{% \boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k}-1)(\Psi(\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_% {k})-\Psi(\sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K}\mbox{\boldmath$\gamma$\unboldmath}_{k^{% \prime}}))- roman_log bold_Œì ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log bold_Œì ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) ( roman_Œ® ( bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Œ® ( ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )
‚àí‚àëj=1J‚àëk=1Kœïj‚Å¢k‚Å¢log‚Å°œïj‚Å¢k.superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêΩsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëóùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëóùëò\displaystyle-\sum_{j=1}^{J}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{jk}\log\phi_{jk}.- ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (19)

Definition and Interpretation of the Loss Function. We can interpret the meaning of each term of ELBO as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Regularization Term for Document-Level Explanations. The sum of the first and the fourth terms, namely ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∂)]‚àíùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùúΩm)]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëöùú∂subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëö{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})]-{{\mathbb{E}}}_{q}[\log q(\mbox{\boldmath$% \theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ± ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], is equal to ‚àíKL(q(ùúΩm)|p(ùúΩm|ùú∂))-KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ± ) ), which is the negation of KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability q‚Å¢(ùúΩm)ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|Œ±)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëöùõºp(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\alpha)italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ± ) of the topic proportion ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for document mùëömitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(ùúΩm)|p(ùúΩm|ùú∂))KL(q(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})|p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$% \unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ± ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred q‚Å¢(ùúΩm)ùëûsubscriptùúΩùëöq(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_q ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its prior distribution p‚Å¢(ùúΩm|ùú∂)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùúΩùëöùú∂p(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}|\mbox{\boldmath$\alpha$\unboldmath})italic_p ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ± ).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Regularization Term for Word-Level Explanations. Similarly, the sum of the second and the last terms (ignoring the summation over the word index jùëójitalic_j for simplicity), namely ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm)]‚àíùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j)]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûsubscriptùëßùëöùëó{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})]-{{% \mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log q(z_{mj})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is equal to ‚àíKL(q(zm‚Å¢j)|p(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm))-KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))- italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), which is the negation of the KL Divergence between the variational posterior probability q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j)ùëûsubscriptùëßùëöùëóq(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the prior probability p‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùúΩùëöp(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the word-level topic assignment zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for word jùëójitalic_j of document mùëömitalic_m. Therefore maximizing the sum of these two terms is equivalent to minimizing the KL Divergence KL(q(zm‚Å¢j)|p(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm))KL(q(z_{mj})|p(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}))italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ); this serves as a regularization term to make sure the inferred q‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j)ùëûsubscriptùëßùëöùëóq(z_{mj})italic_q ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is close to its ‚Äòprior‚Äô distribution p‚Å¢(zm‚Å¢j|ùúΩm)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùúΩùëöp(z_{mj}|\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m})italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Likelihood Term to Indicate How Much FLM Information is Explained. The third term ‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)]superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{{\mathbb{E}}_{q}}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|z_{mj},\mbox% {\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{z_{% mj}})]‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] is to maximize the log likelihood p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëóp({\bf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of every contextual embedding ùêûm‚Å¢jsubscriptùêûùëöùëó{\bf e}_{mj}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (for word jùëójitalic_j of document mùëömitalic_m) conditioned on the inferred zm‚Å¢jsubscriptùëßùëöùëóz_{mj}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the parameters (ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)subscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}% _{z_{mj}})( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In this way, we expand the ELBO to a concrete loss function. Each line of Eq. B corresponds to the expansion of each of the five terms in the ELBO mentioned above (i.e., Eq. 2 in the paper).

Appendix C Experimental Settings and Implementation Details

We will release all code, models, and data. Below we provide more details on the experimental settings and practical implementation.

Data Preprocessing and More Datasets.

We follow Terragni et al. (2021) and Zhang et al. (2022) to pre-process these datasets. The statistics of the datasets are summarized in Table 5. We use the standard 8:1:1 train/validation/test set split. We also use the GLUE benchmark (Wang et al., 2018) to perform additional conceptual interpretation in this section and Sec. F. This benchmark includes multiple sub-tasks of predictions, with the paired sentences as inputs. In this paper, we use 4 datasets from GLUE (MRPC, RTE, STS-B, and QQP) to show contextual interpretations. Specifically, we apply VALC to multiple complex natural language understanding (NLU) tasks in the GLUE benchmark. For example, in Appendix F, we show the three-level conceptual explanations of four different tasks in the GLUE benchmark using VALC, i.e.,

  • ‚Ä¢

    Microsoft Research Paraphrase Corpus (MRPC), where the task is paraphrase identification and semantic textual similarity,

  • ‚Ä¢

    Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE), where the task is to determine whether one sentence (the premise) entails another sentence (the hypothesis),

  • ‚Ä¢

    Semantic Textual Similarity Benchmark (STS-B), where the task is to measure the degree of semantic similarity between pairs of sentences (from 0 to 5), and

  • ‚Ä¢

    Quora Question Pairs (QQP), where the task is to classify whether one question is the duplicate of the other.

Implementation. We implemented and trained the model using PyTorch Paszke et al. (2019) on an A5000 GPU with 24GB of memory. The training duration was kept under a few hours for all datasets. We utilized the Adam optimizer Kingma and Ba (2014) with initial learning rates varying between 10‚àí5‚àº10‚àí3similar-tosuperscript105superscript10310^{-5}\sim 10^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àº 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tailored to the specific requirements of each dataset.

Visualization Postprocessing. For better showcase the dataset-level concepts as in Fig. 4 of the main paper, we may employ simple linear transformations on the embedding of words after the aforementioned PCA step, in order to scatter all the informative words on the same figures. However, for some datasets such as STS-B, this is not necessary; therefore we do not use it for these datasets.

Topic (Concept) Identification. Inspired by Blei et al. (2003), we identify meaningful topics by listing the top-5 topics for each word, computing the inverse document frequency (IDF), and filtering out topics with the lowest IDF scores. Note that although GLUE benchmark are datasets that consists of documents with small size, making it particularly challenging for traditional topic models (such as LDA) to learn topics; interestingly our VALC can still perform well in learning the topics. We contribute this to the following observations: (1) Compared to traditional LDA using discrete word representations, VALC uses continuous word embeddings. In such a continuous space, topics learned for one word can also help neighboring words; this alleviates the sparsity issue caused by short documents and therefore learns better topics. (2) VALC‚Äôs attention-based continuous word counts further improves sample efficiency. In VALC, important words have larger attention weights and therefore larger continuous word counts. In this case, one important word in a sentence possesses statistical (sample) power equivalent to multiple words; this leads to better sample efficiency in VALC.

Computational Complexity. Our VALC introduces minimal overhead in terms of model training cost. Specifically, VALC‚Äôs computational complexity is O‚Å¢(T‚Å¢K‚Å¢d2)ùëÇùëáùêæsuperscriptùëë2O(TKd^{2})italic_O ( italic_T italic_K italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where TùëáTitalic_T is the number of epochs (a small number, such as 3, is sufficient for convergence), KùêæKitalic_K is the number of concepts, and dùëëditalic_d is the dimension of the embeddings (in hidden layers). This means that VALC‚Äôs computational cost scales linearly with the number of concepts KùêæKitalic_K (similar to existing methods).

More NLP Tasks. VALC can be naturally applied to other NLP tasks, such as named entity recognition (NER), reading comprehension, or question answering. Specifically, these tasks involve transformer predictions from multiple positions within the context, rather than relying solely on the ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô token. For example, NER predicts each token in the document as the beginning (‚ÄòB‚Äô) of an entity, the inside (‚ÄòI‚Äô) of entities, etc. To accommodate this and use VALC to explain each token jùëójitalic_j in the context, we can substitute the attention from the ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô token with (1) the attention from the ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô token to all tokens of the previous layer with (2) the attention from token jùëójitalic_j to all tokens of the previous layer in transformers (e.g., using the attention weights from the predicted label ‚ÄòB‚Äô to all tokens of the previous layer as ùêömsubscriptùêöùëö{\bf a}_{m}bold_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in VALC). This adaptation allows VALC to maintain its explanatory power across various NLP applications, demonstrating its versatility and effectiveness in a wide range of tasks.

Appendix D More Details on Concept Editing

We perform concept pruning to the CLS embeddings for VALC (details in Alg. 2). Since BERTopic and CETopic can infer concepts (topics) only at the document level, their only choice is to prune a concept by completely removing input tokens assigned to the concept (as mentioned in Sec. 5.1 and 5.2). To compare our learned concepts with the baseline models, we first follow their configurations (Grootendorst, 2020; Zhang et al., 2022) to fix BERT model parameters when learning the topics/concepts, train a classifier on top of the fixed contextual embeddings, and then perform concept pruning (Koh et al., 2020) for different evaluated models on the same classifier. Note that concept editing is deterministic; therefore, we conduct our experiments with a single run.

Specifically, we assume each BERT model contains a backbone and a classifier. To perform concept editing:

  • (1)

    We first train a classifier on top of the fixed BERT embeddings generated by the fixed backbone to get the original accuracy in the ‚ÄòUnedited‚Äô column (in Table 2 and Table 3 of the main paper).

  • (2)

    We then apply the same embedding cluster methods to these BERT embeddings to infer the concepts/topics for each dataset.

  • (3)

    Finally, with the inferred concepts/topics from the baselines (SHAP/LIME, BERTopic and CETopic in Table 2 of the main paper) and our VALC variants (Unweighted and Weighted in Table 3 of the main paper), we perform concept editing and feed the concept-edited embeddings into the trained classifier from Step (1) to compute the editing accuracy for different methods.

Since here one does not fully finetune the BERT model (i.e., keeping the backbone fixed), the editing accuracy is expected to be lower than the ‚ÄòFinetune‚Äô column (in Table 2 and Table 3 of the main paper), which serves as the oracle. Table 2 of the main paper shows that our VALC learns better concepts than the baselines, and Table 3 of the main paper shows that the weighted variant of VALC performs better.

Note that SHAP and LIME both interpret the CLS token‚Äôs embedding, and hence their concept vectors have the same dimension as the FLM embedding vector (768 in our case). When we conduct concept editing on the kùëòkitalic_k‚Äôth dimension/concept, we simply subtract the CLS embedding‚Äôs dimension kùëòkitalic_k with the average value in the batch on dimension kùëòkitalic_k (which means that we know little about the concept/dimension kùëòkitalic_k on this document), and keep values of the other dimensions unchanged. Note that the pruning process is exactly the same for SHAP and LIME. Therefore SHAP and LIME have identical test accuracy and accuracy gain.

Document-Level Concept Editing. We describe the document-level concept editing algorithm of VALC in Alg. 3. cmsubscriptùëêùëöc_{m}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô embedding of document mùëömitalic_m (see Fig. 2 of the main paper).

Appendix E Connections Between the Defined Properties and Empirical Results

VALC is able to show which words or embeddings contributed to the document-level concept kùëòkitalic_k. Specifically, our variational parameter (a vector) œïm‚Å¢j‚àà‚ÑùKsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëósuperscript‚Ñùùêæ\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT describes how much word jùëójitalic_j contributes to document mùëömitalic_m. For example, the kùëòkitalic_k-th entry of œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ksubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò\phi_{mjk}italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the paper, describes how much word jùëójitalic_j contributes to document mùëömitalic_m in terms of concept kùëòkitalic_k. Therefore, one could use arg‚Å°maxj‚Å°œïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢ksubscriptùëósubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëò\arg\max_{j}\phi_{mjk}roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to find the word that contributes most to document mùëömitalic_m‚Äôs concept kùëòkitalic_k. Below, we will explain these four properties using Fig. 4 as a running example.

  • (1)

    Multi-Level Structure ensures that VALC learns the dataset-, document-, and word-level concepts jointly. In Fig. 4:

    • ‚Äì

      Dataset-level concepts are highlighted by the top words of each concept (the top right box of Fig. 4) and the distribution of their embeddings in the FLM (left and middle figures of Fig. 4); for example, Concept 5 (data analysis) is marked in red.

    • ‚Äì

      Document-level concepts are demonstrated by each document‚Äôs topic; for instance, in the box for document (a) in Fig. 4 (right), VALC identifies Topic (Concept) 5 as key to the FLM‚Äôs prediction of the label 3 (computer science).

    • ‚Äì

      Word-level concepts are identified by words in documents. For example, in the box for document (a) in Fig. 4, VALC highlights the words ‚Äògenetic‚Äô and ‚Äòneural‚Äô because they are highly related to Concept 5 (data analysis). Terms like ‚Äògenetic algorithms‚Äô and ‚Äòneural networks‚Äô are related to data analysis, aligning with the document-level concept.

  • (2)

    Normalization ensures that concept learning is regulated and smoothed, with inferred concepts appearing reasonable. Specifically, in the document-level explanation ùúΩmsubscriptùúΩùëö\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m}bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and word-level explanation œïm‚Å¢jsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëöùëó\mbox{\boldmath$\phi$\unboldmath}_{mj}bold_italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all concepts are assigned a value within the range of 0‚àº1similar-to010\sim 10 ‚àº 1, and all entries sum up to 1, i.e., ‚àëk=1Kœïm‚Å¢i‚Å¢j‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëñùëóùëò1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\phi_{mijk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_i italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and ‚àëk=1KŒ∏m‚Å¢k=1superscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæsubscriptùúÉùëöùëò1\sum_{k=1}^{K}\theta_{mk}=1‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. This introduces ‚Äòcompetition‚Äô among different concepts; a larger strength for one concept means smaller strength for other concepts. Therefore, together with the help of the Dirichlet prior, it implicitly encourages sparser concept-level explanations Œ∏msubscriptùúÉùëö\theta_{m}italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are more aligned with humans‚Äô cognitive processes and more human-understandable (humans tend to make decisions with a small set of concepts).

  • (3)

    Additivity enables FLMs to incorporate relevant concepts and exclude irrelevant ones, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy (as shown in Table 2 and Table 3). For example, in document (a) of Fig. 4, VALC identifies Concept 5 as a highly related concept, distinguishing it from less related concepts. In practice, this may help practitioners identify key concepts in model prediction and more effectively intervene to improve model prediction accuracy (e.g., an expert may find that a concept is relevant and manually down-weight the concept to enhance the model‚Äôs prediction).

  • (4)

    Mutual Information Maximization ensures a strong correlation between (1) VALC‚Äôs generated concept explanations and (2) the explained model‚Äôs representation and predictions. In other words, it ensures that VALC is explaining the target FLM, rather than generating concept explanations irrelevant to the target FLM. For instance, in document (a) of Fig. 4, the inferred document-level Concept 5 (data analysis) effectively explains the FLM prediction, i.e., label 3 (computer science), by highlighting the intrinsic link between the data analysis concept and the class label computer science. This connection is evidenced by the words in dataset-level Concept 5 (top right box). The mutual information between the inferred Concept 5 (data analysis) and label 3 (computer science) contributes to generating high-quality explanations.

Appendix F More Conceptual Interpretation Results in Different Downstream Tasks

Dataset-Level Interpretations. As in the main paper, we leverage VALC as an interpreter on MRPC, RTE, STS-B and QQP, respectively, sample 3,3,4,433443,3,4,43 , 3 , 4 , 4 concepts (topics) for each dataset respectively, and plot the word embeddings of the top words (closest to the center ùùÅisubscriptùùÅùëñ\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{i}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in these concepts using PCA. Fig. 6(left) shows the concepts from MRPC. We can observe Concept 20 is mostly about policing, including words such as ‚Äòsuspect‚Äô, ‚Äòpolice‚Äô, and ‚Äòhouse‚Äô. Concept 24 is mostly about politics, including words such as ‚Äòcapital‚Äô, ‚ÄòCongress‚Äô, and ‚ÄòSenate‚Äô. Concept 27 contains mostly names such as ‚ÄòMargaret‚Äô and ‚ÄòMary‚Äô. Similarly, Fig. 6(right) shows the concepts from RTE. We can observe Concept 67 is related to West Asia and includes words such as ‚ÄòQuran‚Äô and ‚ÄòPasha‚Äô. Concept 13 is related to Europe and includes European countries/names such as ‚ÄòPrussia‚Äô and ‚ÄòSalzburg‚Äô. Concept 91 is mostly about healthcare and includes words such as ‚Äòphysiology‚Äô and ‚Äòinsulin‚Äô. Fig. 7 shows the concepts from STS-B. We can observe Concept 63 is mostly about household and daily life, including words such as ‚Äòtrash‚Äô, ‚Äòflowers‚Äô, ‚Äòairs‚Äô, and ‚Äògarden‚Äô. Concept 60 is mostly about tools, including words such as ‚Äòstations‚Äô, ‚Äòrope‚Äô, ‚Äòparachute‚Äô, and ‚Äòhose‚Äô. Concept 84 is mostly about national security, including words such as ‚Äòguerilla‚Äô, ‚ÄòNSA‚Äô, ‚Äòespionage‚Äô, and ‚Äòraided‚Äô. Concept 55 contains mostly countries and cities such as ‚ÄòKiev‚Äô, ‚ÄòMoscow‚Äô, ‚ÄòAlgeria‚Äô, and ‚ÄòUkrainian‚Äô. Similarly, Fig. 8 shows the concepts from QQP. We can observe that Concept 12 is mostly about negative attitude, including words such as ‚Äòboring‚Äô, ‚Äòcriticism‚Äô, and ‚Äôblame‚Äô. Concept 73 is mostly about Psychology, including words such as ‚Äòadrenaline‚Äô, ‚Äòhaunting‚Äô, and ‚Äôparanoia‚Äô. Concept 34 is mostly about prevention and conservatives, including words such as ‚Äòdestroys‚Äô, ‚Äòunacceptable‚Äô, and ‚Äôprohibits‚Äô. Concept 64 is mostly about strategies, including words such as ‚Äòrumours‚Äô, ‚Äòboycott‚Äô, and ‚Äôdeportation‚Äô.

Document-Level Interpretations. For document-level conceptual interpretations, we sample two example documents from MRPC (Fig. 6(left)), three from RTE (Fig. 6(right)), six from STS-B (Fig. 7) and eight from QQP (Fig. 8), respectively, where each document contains a pair of sentences. The MRPC task is to predict whether one sentence paraphrases the other. For example, in the first document of MRPC, we can see that our VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô with Concept 24 (politics). The RTE task is to predict whether one sentence entail the other. For example, in the second document of RTE, VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô with Concept 13 (countries). The STS-B task is to predict the semantic similarity between two sentences with the score range of [0,5]05[0,5][ 0 , 5 ]. For example, in Document (a) of Fig. 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the model‚Äôs predicted similarity score ‚Äò0.1180.1180.1180.118‚Äô (which is relatively low,) with Concept 63 (household and daily life) and Concept 60 (tools). Similarly, in Document (f) of Fig. 7, we can see that VALC correctly interpret the model‚Äôs predicted similarity score ‚Äò4.6724.6724.6724.672‚Äô (which is relatively high) with Concept 84 (national security). The QQP task is to predict whether the two questions are paraphrase of each other. For example, in Document (b) of Fig. 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the model‚Äôs predicted label ‚ÄòFalse‚Äô with Concept 73 (Psychology). Similarly, in Document (e) of Fig. 8, we can see that VALC correctly interprets the model‚Äôs predicted label ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô with Concept 64 (strategies).

Word-Level Interpretations. For word-level conceptual interpretations, we can observe that VALC interpret the FLM‚Äôs prediction on MRPC‚Äôs first document (Fig. 6(left)) using words such as ‚Äòsenate‚Äô and ‚Äòbitty‚Äô that are related to politics. Note that the word ‚Äòbitty‚Äô is commonly used (with ‚Äòlittle‚Äô) by politicians to refer to the small size of tax relief/cut plans. Similarly, for RTE‚Äôs first document (Fig. 6(right)), VALC correctly identifies Concept 67 (West Asia) and interprets the model prediction ‚ÄòFalse‚Äô by distinguishing between keywords such as ‚ÄòJihad‚Äô and ‚ÄòAl Qaeda‚Äô. likewise, we can observe that VALC interprets FLM‚Äôs prediction on Document (c) of Fig. 7 using words such as ‚Äòcat‚Äô, ‚Äòfloor‚Äô, and ‚Äògarlic‚Äô that are related to household and daily life. Also, VALC interprets FLM‚Äôs prediction on Document (e) of Fig. 7 using words such as ‚Äòsoldier‚Äô and ‚Äòborder‚Äô that are related to national security. Similarly, for QQP‚Äôs Document (d) (Fig. 8), VALC correctly interprets the model prediction ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô by identifying keywords such as ‚Äòsabotage‚Äô and ‚Äòoppose‚Äô with similar meanings in the topic of strategies. For QQP‚Äôs Document (g), (Fig. 8), VALC interprets the words in the both sentences with the same semantics, such as ‚Äòconservative‚Äô that is related to prevention and conservatives (note that in politics, ‚Äòconservative‚Äô refers to parties that tend to prevent/block new policies or legislation), and thereby predicting the correct label ‚ÄòTrue‚Äô.

Example Concepts.

Following Blei et al. (2003), we show the learned concepts on the RTE dataset in Table 6, which is complementary to aforementioned explanations. We select several different topics from Fig. 6. As in Sec. 5.4 of the main paper, we obtain top words from each concept via first calculating the average of the each word‚Äôs corresponding contextual embeddings over the dataset, and then getting the nearest words to each topic center (ùùÅksubscriptùùÅùëò\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k}bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) in the embedding space. As we can see in Table 6, VALC can capture various concepts with profound and accurate semantics. Therefore, although FLM embeddings are contextual and continuous, our VALC can still find conceptual patterns of words on the dataset-level.

Appendix G More Quantitative Results.

Document Classification with VALC Concepts. We conducted additional experiments to perform document classification using the ‚ÄòCLS‚Äô token‚Äôs embedding and ùúΩùúΩ\thetabold_italic_Œ∏ (inferred from VALC) as features. Table 7 shows the results on three datasets. The results show that our VALC can learn meaningful concept vector ùúΩùúΩ\thetabold_italic_Œ∏, which can improve model predictions of document labels.

Appendix H Theory on the Mutual Information Maximization Property

We provide the following proof of Theorem 4.1 of the main paper.

For convenience, let Œ©=(ùùÅk=1K,Œ£k=1K)Œ©superscriptsubscriptùùÅùëò1ùêæsuperscriptsubscriptŒ£ùëò1ùêæ\Omega=(\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k=1}^{K},\Sigma_{k=1}^{K})roman_Œ© = ( bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , roman_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and Œ≤=(ùúΩm,ùê≥m)ùõΩsubscriptùúΩùëösubscriptùê≥ùëö\beta=(\mbox{\boldmath$\theta$\unboldmath}_{m},{\bf z}_{m})italic_Œ≤ = ( bold_italic_Œ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

We then introduce a helper joint distribution of the variables ùêûmsubscriptùêûùëö{\bf e}_{m}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Œ≤ùõΩ\betaitalic_Œ≤, s‚Å¢(ùêûm,Œ≤)=p‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢q‚Å¢(Œ≤|ùêûm)ùë†subscriptùêûùëöùõΩùëùsubscriptùêûùëöùëûconditionalùõΩsubscriptùêûùëös({\bf e}_{m},\beta)=p({\bf e}_{m})q(\beta|{\bf e}_{m})italic_s ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Œ≤ ) = italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ | bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

According to the definition of ELBO of Section 3.4.1, in Eq. 4.1, we have

L‚Å¢H‚Å¢S=‚Ñí‚Å¢(Œ≥m,œïm;Œ±,Œ©)=ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢(Œ≤)‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ©,Œ≤)]]+ùîºq‚Å¢(Œ≤)‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(Œ≤|Œ©)].ùêøùêªùëÜ‚Ñísubscriptùõæùëösubscriptitalic-œïùëöùõºŒ©subscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûùõΩdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöŒ©ùõΩsubscriptùîºùëûùõΩdelimited-[]ùëûconditionalùõΩŒ©\displaystyle LHS={\mathcal{L}}(\gamma_{m},\phi_{m};\alpha,\Omega)={\mathbb{E}% }_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log p({\bf e}_{m}|\Omega,\beta)]]+% {\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log q(\beta|\Omega)].italic_L italic_H italic_S = caligraphic_L ( italic_Œ≥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ± , roman_Œ© ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | roman_Œ© , italic_Œ≤ ) ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ | roman_Œ© ) ] . (20)

Since ùîºq‚Å¢(Œ≤)‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(Œ≤|Œ©)]‚â§0subscriptùîºùëûùõΩdelimited-[]ùëûconditionalùõΩŒ©0{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log q(\beta|\Omega)]\leq 0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ | roman_Œ© ) ] ‚â§ 0, we only need to prove that

ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢(Œ≤)‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ©,Œ≤)]]‚â§Is‚Å¢(ùêûm;Œ≤)‚àíH‚Å¢(ùêûm)=R‚Å¢H‚Å¢S.subscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûùõΩdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöŒ©ùõΩsubscriptùêºùë†subscriptùêûùëöùõΩùêªsubscriptùêûùëöùëÖùêªùëÜ\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q(\beta)}[\log p({\bf e% }_{m}|\Omega,\beta)]]\leq I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})=RHS.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_Œ≤ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | roman_Œ© , italic_Œ≤ ) ] ] ‚â§ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ≤ ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_R italic_H italic_S . (21)

Then we have that

ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤,Œ©)]]subscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩŒ©\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{m}% |\beta,\Omega)]]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ , roman_Œ© ) ] ] ‚â§ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)]]absentsubscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩ\displaystyle\leq{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}% _{m}|\beta)]]‚â§ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) ] ]
=ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)p‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢p‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)q‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)]]absentsubscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩùëùsubscriptùêûùëöùëùsubscriptùêûùëöùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩùëûconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩ\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log\tfrac{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}{p({\bf e}_{m})}\tfrac{p({\bf e}_{m})p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}]]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG ] ]
=ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°q‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)p‚Å¢(ùêûm)]]+ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm)]]+ùîºp‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚Å¢[ùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)q‚Å¢(ùêûm|Œ≤)]]absentsubscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëûconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩùëùsubscriptùêûùëösubscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùsubscriptùêûùëösubscriptùîºùëùsubscriptùêûùëödelimited-[]subscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩùëûconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùõΩ\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log\tfrac{q({\bf e% }_{m}|\beta)}{p({\bf e}_{m})}]]+{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}% [\log p({\bf e}_{m})]]+{\mathbb{E}}_{p({\bf e}_{m})}[{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log% \tfrac{p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}{q({\bf e}_{m}|\beta)}]]= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) end_ARG ] ]
=Is(ùêûm;Œ≤)‚àíH(ùêûm)‚àíùîºq[KL(q(ùêûm|Œ≤)|p(ùêûm|Œ≤))]\displaystyle=I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})-{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[KL(q({% \bf e}_{m}|\beta)|p({\bf e}_{m}|\beta))]= italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ≤ ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_K italic_L ( italic_q ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) | italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Œ≤ ) ) ]
‚â§Is‚Å¢(ùêûm;Œ≤)‚àíH‚Å¢(ùêûm)‚àí0=R‚Å¢H‚Å¢S,absentsubscriptùêºùë†subscriptùêûùëöùõΩùêªsubscriptùêûùëö0ùëÖùêªùëÜ\displaystyle\leq I_{s}({\bf e}_{m};\beta)-H({\bf e}_{m})-0=RHS,‚â§ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Œ≤ ) - italic_H ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - 0 = italic_R italic_H italic_S , (22)

which concludes the proof of Theorem 4.1.

Appendix I Theoretical Analysis on Continuous Word Counts

Before going to the claims and proofs, first we specify some basic problem settings and assumptions. Suppose there are K+1ùêæ1K+1italic_K + 1 topic groups, each of which is regarded to be sampled from a parameterized multivariate Gaussian distribution. In specific, the K+1ùêæ1K+1italic_K + 1 ‚Äôth distribution of topic has a much larger covariance, and in the same time, closed to the center of embedding space. The prementioned properties can be measured by a series of inequalities:

The approximate marginal log-likelihood of word embeddings, i.e., the third term of the ELBO as mentioned in Eqn. 2 of the main paper, is:

‚Ñí(t‚Å¢r‚Å¢a‚Å¢i‚Å¢n)superscript‚Ñíùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{(train)}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =‚àëj=1Jmùîºq‚Å¢[log‚Å°p‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j|zm‚Å¢j,ùùÅzm‚Å¢j,ùö∫zm‚Å¢j)]absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùêΩùëösubscriptùîºùëûdelimited-[]ùëùconditionalsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùùÅsubscriptùëßùëöùëósubscriptùö∫subscriptùëßùëöùëó\displaystyle=\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{J_{m}}{\mathbb{E}}_{q}[\log p({\bf e}_{mj}|% z_{mj},\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{z_{mj}},\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$% \unboldmath}_{z_{mj}})]= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_p ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ]
=‚àëm,j,kœïm‚Å¢j‚Å¢k‚Å¢wm‚Å¢j‚Å¢{‚àí12‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)T‚Å¢ùö∫k‚àí1‚Å¢(ùêûm‚Å¢j‚àíùùÅk)‚àílog‚Å°[(2‚Å¢œÄ)d/2‚Å¢|ùö∫k|1/2]}.absentsubscriptùëöùëóùëòsubscriptitalic-œïùëöùëóùëòsubscriptùë§ùëöùëó12superscriptsubscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòùëásuperscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò1subscriptùêûùëöùëósubscriptùùÅùëòsuperscript2ùúãùëë2superscriptsubscriptùö∫ùëò12\displaystyle=\sum_{m,j,k}\phi_{mjk}w_{mj}\{-\tfrac{1}{2}({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{% \boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})^{T}\mbox{\boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}^{-1% }({\bf e}_{mj}-\mbox{\boldmath$\mu$\unboldmath}_{k})-\log[(2\pi)^{d/2}|\mbox{% \boldmath$\Sigma$\unboldmath}_{k}|^{1/2}]\}.= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m , italic_j , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_œï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Œº start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_log [ ( 2 italic_œÄ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_Œ£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] } . (23)

The above equation is the training objective, yet for fair comparison of different training schemes, we calculate the approximated likelihood with word count 1111 for all words.
